trans-unit.source: Using XA with the network client driver

seg-source.mrk: Using XA with the network client driver

target.mrk: Using XA with the network client driver

trans-unit.source: You can access XA support for the Network Server by using the network client driver's XA DataSource interface.

seg-source.mrk: You can access XA support for the Network Server by using the network client driver's XA DataSource interface.

target.mrk: You can access XA support for the Network Server by using the network client driver's XA DataSource interface.

trans-unit.source: Using with the network client driver

seg-source.mrk: Using with the network client driver

target.mrk: Using with the network client driver

trans-unit.source: You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource</codeph> class on Java SE 5 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 3 or JDBC 4.0 methods. You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 6 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 4.1 or JDBC 4.2 methods. You must use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.BasicClientXADataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 8 Compact Profile 2 or 3.

seg-source.mrk: You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource</codeph> class on Java SE 5 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 3 or JDBC 4.0 methods.
You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 6 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 4.1 or JDBC 4.2 methods.
You must use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.BasicClientXADataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 8 Compact Profile 2 or 3.

target.mrk: You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource</codeph> class on Java SE 5 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 3 or JDBC 4.0 methods.
You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 6 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 4.1 or JDBC 4.2 methods.
You must use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.BasicClientXADataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 8 Compact Profile 2 or 3.

trans-unit.source: If your client is running on the Java SE 6 platform or higher, all connection objects returned from the DataSource will be JDBC 4 connection objects, whether or not you are using a DataSource whose name ends in "40".

seg-source.mrk: If your client is running on the Java SE 6 platform or higher, all connection objects returned from the DataSource will be JDBC 4 connection objects, whether or not you are using a DataSource whose name ends in "40".

target.mrk: If your client is running on the Java SE 6 platform or higher, all connection objects returned from the DataSource will be JDBC 4 connection objects, whether or not you are using a DataSource whose name ends in "40".

trans-unit.source: The following example illustrates how to obtain an XA connection with the network client driver:

seg-source.mrk: The following example illustrates how to obtain an XA connection with the network client driver:

target.mrk: The following example illustrates how to obtain an XA connection with the network client driver:

trans-unit.source: import org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource; import javax.sql.XAConnection; ... XAConnection xaConnection = null; Connection conn = null; ClientXADataSource ds = new ClientXADataSource(); ds.setDatabaseName ("sample"); ds.setCreateDatabase("create"); ds.setServerName("localhost"); ds.setPortNumber(1527); xaConnection = ds.getXAConnection("auser", "shhhh"); conn = xaConnection.getConnection();

seg-source.mrk: XAConnection xaConnection = null; Connection conn = null; ClientXADataSource ds = new ClientXADataSource(); ds.setDatabaseName ("sample"); ds.setCreateDatabase("create"); ds.setServerName("localhost"); ds.setPortNumber(1527); xaConnection = ds.getXAConnection("auser", "shhhh"); conn = xaConnection.getConnection();

target.mrk: XAConnection xaConnection = null; Connection conn = null; ClientXADataSource ds = new ClientXADataSource(); ds.setDatabaseName ("sample"); ds.setCreateDatabase("create"); ds.setServerName("localhost"); ds.setPortNumber(1527); xaConnection = ds.getXAConnection("auser", "shhhh"); conn = xaConnection.getConnection();
